title: 115_hr3054
content: The "Veterans' Heritage Firearms Act of 2017" allows veterans an amnesty period to register qualifying firearms. During the amnesty period, veterans or their family members can register qualifying firearms in the National Firearms Registration and Transfer Record. A qualifying firearm is one acquired before October 31, 1968, by a veteran while stationed outside the continental United States. The Attorney General must be provided with clear and convincing evidence to challenge the validity of the registration. During the amnesty period, veterans or their family members can register qualifying firearms in the National Firearms Registration and Transfer Record. The Attorney General will accept as true any evidence submitted to prove a firearm meets requirements. If registration is denied, the individual can request a hearing to review the decision. Individuals registering firearms under this section receive limited immunity from criminal liability under title 18. Individuals who lawfully acquired and possessed firearms before the enactment of chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, are not liable for violations of that chapter related to ownership, possession, transportation, importation, or alteration of the firearm. Registering a firearm under subsection (a) provides limited immunity from criminal liability under the internal revenue code. Registering a firearm under subsection (a) provides limited immunity from criminal liability under the internal revenue code. Transfer tax liability is not affected by this registration. If an applicable veteran or their family member tries to register a firearm outside the amnesty period, they must surrender it to law enforcement within 30 days. The Attorney General must be notified within 30 days of potential criminal liability for possessing a firearm. Registered firearms are not subject to seizure or forfeiture for violations before or during registration. The Attorney General will provide clear notices about the amnesty period for firearm registration. The Attorney General will provide clear notices about the amnesty period for firearm registration, including outreach to veterans and making registration forms available in various locations and online. During the amnesty period, the Attorney General will accept forms postmarked within the 180-day period. The term "firearm" is defined in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, excluding certain devices and parts. The term "applicable veteran" refers to the veteran mentioned in subsection (b)(1) regarding a firearm, while the term "veteran" is defined in section 101(2) of title 38, United States Code. The term "family" includes grandparents, lineal descendants, and spouses of lineal descendants of a veteran. The term "continental United States" excludes Alaska and Hawaii, referring to the several States and the District of Columbia. Special rules apply for spouses legally separated under a decree of divorce or separate maintenance, and for individuals related by half blood or legal adoption. TRANSFER OF FIREARMS TO MUSEUMS. The Attorney General transfers forfeited firearms to museums upon request, prohibits their destruction for 5 years, and publishes information about available firearms online. The Attorney General transfers forfeited firearms to museums upon request, prohibits their destruction for 5 years, and publishes firearm information online for public access without cost or restriction. Firearms transferred to qualified museums must be registered in the National Firearms Registration and Transfer Record. The term "firearm" refers to any curio or relic as defined in the law. A qualified museum is defined as any museum owned or operated by a unit of. Qualified museums, as defined by law, include those owned or operated by a government unit or incorporated as not-for-profit entities. These museums must be open to the public, possess firearms in their collection as allowed by state laws, hold a collector's license under federal law, and certify to the Attorney General that they are not engaged in the firearms trade. The museum, if qualified, can transfer firearms without intent to sell, and must apply to transfer any machinegun within 90 days of ceasing operations. Transfer of machineguns to museums can be done by a museum that is open to the public and incorporated as a not-for-profit corporation under applicable State law.
